pr_title: add methods for getting applications within specified date period

timeline.message: add methods for getting applications within specified date period

timeline.body:
Generally, we want to use one policy for one method. Please, create a new policy in the `perun-base/src/main/resources/perun-roles.yml` file.
```suggestion
		if (!AuthzResolver.authorizedInternal(userSession, "getApplicationsForVo_Vo_List<String>_String_String_policy", Collections.singletonList(vo))) {
```

timeline.body:
This SQL seems to be invalid. If you would use the LocalDate, you can fix it like this
```suggestion
				return jdbc.query(APP_SELECT + " where a.vo_id=? and a.created_at::date >= ? and a.created_at::date <= ? order by a.id desc", APP_MAPPER, vo.getId(), dateFrom, dateTo);
```
timeline.bodyHTML:
This SQL seems to be invalid. If you would use the LocalDate, you can fix it like this

Suggested change
return jdbc.query(APP_SELECT + " where a.vo_id=? and a.created_at::date >= date ? and a.create_at::date <= date ? order by a.id desc", APP_MAPPER, vo.getId(), dateFrom, dateTo);
return jdbc.query(APP_SELECT + " where a.vo_id=? and a.created_at::date >= ? and a.created_at::date <= ? order by a.id desc", APP_MAPPER, vo.getId(), dateFrom, dateTo);
timeline.author: Vojtech-Sassmann

timeline.body:
This SQL seems to be invalid. If you would use the LocalDate, you can fix it like this
```suggestion
				return namedJdbc.query(APP_SELECT + " where a.vo_id=:voId and state in ( :states ) and a.created_at::date >= :from and a.created_at::date <= :to order by a.id desc", sqlParameterSource, APP_MAPPER);
```
timeline.bodyHTML:
This SQL seems to be invalid. If you would use the LocalDate, you can fix it like this

Suggested change
return namedJdbc.query(APP_SELECT + " where a.vo_id=:voId and state in ( :states ) and a.created_at::date >= date :from and a.create_at::date <= date :to order by a.id desc", sqlParameterSource, APP_MAPPER);
return namedJdbc.query(APP_SELECT + " where a.vo_id=:voId and state in ( :states ) and a.created_at::date >= :from and a.created_at::date <= :to order by a.id desc", sqlParameterSource, APP_MAPPER);
timeline.author: Vojtech-Sassmann

This is not necessary, but there is also a method for parsing LocalDates. I would suggest using it instead of the String. Same for other similar usages.
```suggestion
						parms.readLocalDate("dateFrom"), 
```

timeline.author: Vojtech-Sassmann
timeline.diffHunk: @@ -479,14 +498,33 @@ public ApplicationFormItem call(ApiCaller ac, Deserializer parms) throws PerunEx * @param state List List of states: NEW, VERIFIED, APPROVED, REJECTED * @return List Found applications */ + /*# + * Gets all applications in a given state for a given Group in a given date period. + * + * @param group int Group id + * @param state List List of states: NEW, VERIFIED, APPROVED, REJECTED + * @param dateFrom String Earliest date for applications + * @param dateTo String Latest date for applications + * @return List Found applications + */ getApplicationsForGroup { @Override public List call(ApiCaller ac, Deserializer parms) throws PerunException { - if (parms.contains("state")) { - return ac.getRegistrarManager().getApplicationsForGroup(ac.getSession(), ac.getGroupById(parms.readInt("group")), parms.readList("state", String.class)); + if (parms.contains("dateFrom")) { + return ac.getRegistrarManager().getApplicationsForGroup( + ac.getSession(), + ac.getGroupById(parms.readInt("group")), + parms.contains("state") ? parms.readList("state", String.class) : null, + parms.readString("dateFrom"),

timeline.body:
This way, you can specify only one bound.
```suggestion
			if (parms.contains("dateFrom") || parms.contains("dateTo")) {
```
timeline.bodyHTML:
This way, you can specify only one bound.

Suggested change
if (parms.contains("dateFrom")) {
if (parms.contains("dateFrom") || parms.contains("dateTo")) {
timeline.author: Vojtech-Sassmann

timeline.bodyHTML:
With this change, it will work even if only one bound is specified.

Suggested change
}
}
if (dateTo == null) {
dateTo = LocalDate.MAX;
}
if (dateFrom == null {
dateFrom = LocalDate.MIN;
}
timeline.author: Vojtech-Sassmann

replies.bodyText: This is extremely ugly from the SQL point of view. I rewrote it.
replies.author: mvocu

timeline.body:
This SQL also seems to be incorrect. This will again work only if you use LocalDates.
```suggestion
				return jdbc.query(APP_SELECT + " where a.group_id=? and a.created_at::date >= ? and a.created_at::date <= ? order by a.id desc", APP_MAPPER, group.getId(), dateFrom, dateTo);
```
timeline.bodyHTML:
This SQL also seems to be incorrect. This will again work only if you use LocalDates.

Suggested change
return jdbc.query(APP_SELECT + " where a.group_id=? and a.created_at::date >= date ? and a.create_at::date <= date ? order by a.id desc", APP_MAPPER, group.getId(), dateFrom, dateTo);
return jdbc.query(APP_SELECT + " where a.group_id=? and a.created_at::date >= ? and a.created_at::date <= ? order by a.id desc", APP_MAPPER, group.getId(), dateFrom, dateTo);
timeline.author: Vojtech-Sassmann

replies.bodyText: I do not understand. AFAIK the SQL is correct and works (tested on command line).
replies.author: mvocu

replies.bodyText:
The column create_at is incorrect. Also, the notation date ? doesn't work in JDBC. I have run it, and it just throws PSQLException: ERROR: syntax error at or near "$2".
Rewritting it to date(?) or ?::date seemed to fix it.
replies.author: Vojtech-Sassmann

timeline.body:
This SQL also seems to be incorrect. This will again work only if you use LocalDates.
```suggestion
				return namedJdbc.query(APP_SELECT + " where a.group_id=:groupId and state in ( :states ) and a.created_at::date >= :from and a.created_at::date <= :to order by a.id desc", sqlParameterSource, APP_MAPPER);
```
timeline.bodyHTML:
This SQL also seems to be incorrect. This will again work only if you use LocalDates.

Suggested change
return namedJdbc.query(APP_SELECT + " where a.group_id=:groupId and state in ( :states ) and a.created_at::date >= date :from and a.create_at::date <= date :to order by a.id desc", sqlParameterSource, APP_MAPPER);
return namedJdbc.query(APP_SELECT + " where a.group_id=:groupId and state in ( :states ) and a.created_at::date >= :from and a.created_at::date <= :to order by a.id desc", sqlParameterSource, APP_MAPPER);
timeline.author: Vojtech-Sassmann

timeline.body: I think that when you specify only the VO, it will also return all group applications within that VO. I know that this is how also the old method works but I am not sure if it is correct. What do you think @zlamalp ?
timeline.bodyText: I think that when you specify only the VO, it will also return all group applications within that VO. I know that this is how also the old method works but I am not sure if it is correct. What do you think @zlamalp ?
timeline.bodyHTML: I think that when you specify only the VO, it will also return all group applications within that VO. I know that this is how also the old method works but I am not sure if it is correct. What do you think @zlamalp ?
timeline.author: balcirakpeter

replies.bodyText:
@balcirakpeter you are right. Original method returns also group applications within the VO on purpose. So the new method should do the same as its expected to be used from the same part of GUI. It was probably just not reflected in javadoc.
@mvocu we should add some kind of boolean flag in API of those methods (defaulting to old behaviour), since I see we use it from AppAutoRejectionScheduler, where it should process only VO applications, but like this it works also on group applications. For now it doesn't have to be in outer API (openAPI/RPC). Its just for the purpose of AppAutoRejectionScheduler.
replies.author: zlamalp

timeline.message: changed type of additional parameters to LocalDate, modified SQL, updated parameter parsing from request, updated policy names to reflect parameter types
add boolean parameter indicating whether to include group applications

+	 * @param state application state to filter by

+	 * @return list of applications
